sn12.35:1.3.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn12.35:1.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.”

sn12.35:1.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.35:1.5.eng: When this was said, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,

sn12.35:1.6.pli: “‘katamaṃ nu kho, bhante, jarāmaraṇaṃ, kassa ca panidaṃ jarāmaraṇan’ti?
sn12.35:1.6.eng: “What are old age and death, sir, and who do they belong to?”

sn12.35:1.7.pli: ‘No kallo pañho’ti bhagavā avoca, ‘katamaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ, kassa ca panidaṃ jarāmaraṇan’ti iti vā, bhikkhu, yo vadeyya, ‘aññaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ aññassa ca panidaṃ jarāmaraṇan’ti, iti vā, bhikkhu, yo vadeyya, ubhayametaṃ ekatthaṃ byañjanameva nānaṃ.
sn12.35:1.7.eng: “That’s not a cogent question,” said the Buddha. “You might say, ‘What are old age and death, and who do they belong to?’ Or you might say, ‘Old age and death are one thing, who they belong to is another.’ But both of these mean the same thing, only the phrasing differs.

sn12.35:1.8.pli: Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti vā, bhikkhu, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti.
sn12.35:1.8.eng: Mendicant, if you have the view that the soul and the body are one and the same, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.35:1.9.pli: Aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti vā, bhikkhu, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti.
sn12.35:1.9.eng: If you have the view that the soul is one thing, the body another, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.35:1.10.pli: Ete te, bhikkhu, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti:
sn12.35:1.10.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:

sn12.35:1.11.eng: ‘Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death.’”

sn12.35:2.1.pli: “Katamā nu kho, bhante, jāti, kassa ca panāyaṃ jātī”ti?
sn12.35:2.1.eng: “What is rebirth, sir, and who does it belong to?”

sn12.35:2.2.pli: “No kallo pañho”ti bhagavā avoca, “‘katamā jāti, kassa ca panāyaṃ jātī’ti iti vā, bhikkhu, yo vadeyya, ‘aññā jāti aññassa ca panāyaṃ jātī’ti iti vā, bhikkhu, yo vadeyya, ubhayametaṃ ekatthaṃ byañjanameva nānaṃ.
sn12.35:2.2.eng: “That’s not a cogent question,” said the Buddha. “You might say, ‘What is rebirth, and who does it belong to?’ Or you might say, ‘Rebirth is one thing, who it belongs to is another.’ But both of these mean the same thing, only the phrasing differs.

sn12.35:2.3.pli: Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti vā, bhikkhu, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti.
sn12.35:2.3.eng: Mendicant, if you have the view that the soul and the body are one and the same, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.35:2.4.pli: Aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti vā, bhikkhu, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti.
sn12.35:2.4.eng: If you have the view that the soul is one thing, the body another, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.35:2.5.pli: Ete te, bhikkhu, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti:
sn12.35:2.5.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:

sn12.35:2.6.eng: ‘Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.’”

sn12.35:3.1.pli: “Katamo nu kho, bhante, bhavo, kassa ca panāyaṃ bhavo”ti?
sn12.35:3.1.eng: “What is continued existence, sir, and who is it for?”

sn12.35:3.2.pli: “No kallo pañho”ti bhagavā avoca, “‘katamo bhavo, kassa ca panāyaṃ bhavo’ti iti vā, bhikkhu, yo vadeyya, ‘añño bhavo aññassa ca panāyaṃ bhavo’ti iti vā, bhikkhu, yo vadeyya, ubhayametaṃ ekatthaṃ byañjanameva nānaṃ.
sn12.35:3.2.eng: “That’s not a cogent question,” said the Buddha. “You might say, ‘What is continued existence, and who does it belong to?’ Or you might say, ‘Continued existence is one thing, who it belongs to is another.’ But both of these mean the same thing, only the phrasing differs.

sn12.35:3.3.pli: Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti vā, bhikkhu, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti;
sn12.35:3.3.eng: Mendicant, if you have the view that the soul and the body are identical, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.35:3.4.pli: aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti vā, bhikkhu, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti.
sn12.35:3.4.eng: If you have the view that the soul is one thing, the body another, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.35:3.5.pli: Ete te, bhikkhu, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti:
sn12.35:3.5.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:

sn12.35:3.6.eng: ‘Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.’ …

sn12.35:3.10.eng: ‘The six sense fields are requirements for contact.’ …

sn12.35:3.11.eng: ‘Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields.’ …

sn12.35:3.12.eng: ‘Consciousness is a requirement for name and form.’ …

sn12.35:4.1.pli: “Katame nu kho, bhante, saṅkhārā, kassa ca panime saṅkhārā”ti?
sn12.35:4.1.eng: “What are choices, sir, and who do they belong to?”

sn12.35:4.2.pli: “No kallo pañho”ti bhagavā avoca, “‘katame saṅkhārā kassa ca panime saṅkhārā’ti iti vā, bhikkhu, yo vadeyya, ‘aññe saṅkhārā aññassa ca panime saṅkhārā’ti iti vā, bhikkhu, yo vadeyya, ubhayametaṃ ekatthaṃ byañjanameva nānaṃ.
sn12.35:4.2.eng: “That’s not a cogent question,” said the Buddha. “You might say, ‘What are choices, and who do they belong to?’ Or you might say, ‘Choices are one thing, who they belong to is another.’ But both of these mean the same thing, only the phrasing differs.

sn12.35:4.3.pli: Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti vā, bhikkhu, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti;
sn12.35:4.3.eng: Mendicant, if you have the view that the soul and the body are one and the same, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.35:4.4.pli: aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti vā, bhikkhu, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti.
sn12.35:4.4.eng: If you have the view that the soul is one thing, the body another, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.35:4.5.pli: Ete te, bhikkhu, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti:
sn12.35:4.5.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:

sn12.35:5.1.pli: “Avijjāya tveva, bhikkhu, asesavirāganirodhā yānissa tāni visūkāyikāni visevitāni vipphanditāni kānici kānici.
sn12.35:5.1.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, then any twists, ducks, and dodges are given up:
sn12.35:5.1.comm: “Twist” (visūka) is used with “dodge” (vipphandita) and sometimes “duck” (visevita) for an horse fighting the bit (MN 65:33.2) or a crab escaping the torment of children (MN 35:23.9). Visūka is also used for a “show” of dance, etc., where the commentarial gloss paṭāṇi (“screw”) reinforces the sense “twist, gyrate”. As descriptions of views, they suggest the active process of denial and distortion through which views shape how we see the world.

sn12.35:5.2.pli: ‘Katamaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ, kassa ca panidaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ’ iti vā, ‘aññaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ, aññassa ca panidaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ’ iti vā, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā.
sn12.35:5.2.eng: ‘What are old age and death, and who do they belong to?’ or ‘old age and death are one thing, who they belong to is another’, or ‘the soul and the body are one and the same’, or ‘the soul is one thing, the body another.’

sn12.35:5.3.pli: Sabbānissa tāni pahīnāni bhavanti ucchinnamūlāni tālāvatthukatāni anabhāvaṅkatāni āyatiṃ anuppādadhammāni.
sn12.35:5.3.eng: These are all cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn12.35:6.1.pli: Avijjāya tveva, bhikkhu, asesavirāganirodhā yānissa tāni visūkāyikāni visevitāni vipphanditāni kānici kānici.
sn12.35:6.1.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, then any twists, ducks, and dodges are given up:

sn12.35:6.2.pli: ‘Katamā jāti, kassa ca panāyaṃ jāti’ iti vā, ‘aññā jāti, aññassa ca panāyaṃ jāti’ iti vā, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā.
sn12.35:6.2.eng: ‘What is rebirth, and who does it belong to?’ or ‘rebirth is one thing, who it belongs to is another’, or ‘the soul and the body are one and the same’, or ‘the soul is one thing, the body another.’

sn12.35:6.3.pli: Sabbānissa tāni pahīnāni bhavanti ucchinnamūlāni tālāvatthukatāni anabhāvaṅkatāni āyatiṃ anuppādadhammāni.
sn12.35:6.3.eng: These are all cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn12.35:7.1.pli: Avijjāya tveva, bhikkhu, asesavirāganirodhā yānissa tāni visūkāyikāni visevitāni vipphanditāni kānici kānici.
sn12.35:7.1.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, then any twists, ducks, and dodges are given up:

sn12.35:8.1.pli: Avijjāya tveva, bhikkhu, asesavirāganirodhā yānissa tāni visūkāyikāni visevitāni vipphanditāni kānici kānici.
sn12.35:8.1.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, then any twists, ducks, and dodges are given up:

sn12.35:8.2.pli: ‘Katame saṅkhārā, kassa ca panime saṅkhārā’ iti vā, ‘aññe saṅkhārā, aññassa ca panime saṅkhārā’ iti vā, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ, aññaṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā.
sn12.35:8.2.eng: ‘What are choices, and who do they belong to?’ or ‘choices are one thing, who they belong to is another’, or ‘the soul and the body are one and the same’, or ‘the soul is one thing, the body another.’

sn12.35:8.3.pli: Sabbānissa tāni pahīnāni bhavanti ucchinnamūlāni tālāvatthukatāni anabhāvaṅkatāni āyatiṃ anuppādadhammānī”ti.
sn12.35:8.3.eng: These are all cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.”

sn12.36:1.3.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn12.36:1.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.36:2.1.pli: ‘Katamaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ, kassa ca panidaṃ jarāmaraṇan’ti iti vā, bhikkhave, yo vadeyya, ‘aññaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ, aññassa ca panidaṃ jarāmaraṇan’ti iti vā, bhikkhave, yo vadeyya, ubhayametaṃ ekatthaṃ byañjanameva nānaṃ.
sn12.36:2.1.eng: Mendicants, you might say, ‘What are old age and death, and who do they belong to?’ Or you might say, ‘Old age and death are one thing, who they belong to is another.’ But both of these mean the same thing, only the phrasing differs.

sn12.36:2.2.pli: ‘Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā, bhikkhave, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti.
sn12.36:2.2.eng: If you have the view that the soul and the body are one and the same, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.36:2.3.pli: ‘Aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā, bhikkhave, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti.
sn12.36:2.3.eng: If you have the view that the soul is one thing, the body another, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.36:2.4.pli: Ete te, bhikkhave, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti:
sn12.36:2.4.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:

sn12.36:2.5.eng: ‘Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death.’

sn12.36:3.10.pli: katame saṅkhārā, kassa ca panime saṅkhārāti iti vā, bhikkhave, yo vadeyya, ‘aññe saṅkhārā aññassa ca panime saṅkhārā’ti iti vā, bhikkhave, yo vadeyya, ubhayametaṃ ekatthaṃ byañjanameva nānaṃ.
sn12.36:3.10.eng: You might say, ‘What are choices, and who do they belong to?’ Or you might say, ‘Choices are one thing, who they belong to is another.’ But both of these mean the same thing, only the phrasing differs.

sn12.36:3.11.pli: ‘Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā, bhikkhave, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti.
sn12.36:3.11.eng: If you have the view that the soul and the body are identical, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.36:3.12.pli: ‘Aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā, bhikkhave, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hoti.
sn12.36:3.12.eng: If you have the view that the soul is one thing, the body another, there is no living of the spiritual life.

sn12.36:3.13.pli: Ete te, bhikkhave, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti:
sn12.36:3.13.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:

sn12.36:4.1.pli: Avijjāya tveva, bhikkhave, asesavirāganirodhā yānissa tāni visūkāyikāni visevitāni vipphanditāni kānici kānici.
sn12.36:4.1.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, then any twists, ducks, and dodges are given up:

sn12.36:4.2.pli: ‘Katamaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ, kassa ca panidaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ’ iti vā, ‘aññaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ, aññassa ca panidaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ’ iti vā, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ, aññaṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā.
sn12.36:4.2.eng: ‘What are old age and death, and who do they belong to?’ or ‘old age and death are one thing, who they belong to is another’, or ‘the soul and the body are identical’, or ‘the soul is one thing, the body another’.

sn12.36:4.3.pli: Sabbānissa tāni pahīnāni bhavanti ucchinnamūlāni tālāvatthukatāni anabhāvaṅkatāni āyatiṃ anuppādadhammāni.
sn12.36:4.3.eng: These are all cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn12.36:5.1.pli: Avijjāya tveva, bhikkhave, asesavirāganirodhā yānissa tāni visūkāyikāni visevitāni vipphanditāni kānici kānici.
sn12.36:5.1.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, then any twists, ducks, and dodges are given up:

sn12.36:5.11.pli: ‘katame saṅkhārā, kassa ca panime saṅkhārā’ iti vā, ‘aññe saṅkhārā, aññassa ca panime saṅkhārā’ iti vā; ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīraṃ’ iti vā.
sn12.36:5.11.eng: ‘What are choices, and who do they belong to?’ or ‘choices are one thing, who they belong to is another’, or ‘the soul and the body are identical’, or ‘the soul is one thing, the body another’.

sn12.36:5.12.pli: Sabbānissa tāni pahīnāni bhavanti ucchinnamūlāni tālāvatthukatāni anabhāvaṅkatāni āyatiṃ anuppādadhammānī”ti.
sn12.36:5.12.eng: These are all cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.”

sn12.37:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, this body doesn’t belong to you or to anyone else.

sn12.37:1.3.pli: Purāṇamidaṃ, bhikkhave, kammaṃ abhisaṅkhataṃ abhisañcetayitaṃ vedaniyaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn12.37:1.3.eng: It’s old deeds, and should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.
sn12.37:1.3.comm: That is to say, the body we bear in this life was created by our intentional deeds or moral choices in a past life, which we experience the result of in this life (see SN 12.19:1.2). Treated in more detail in SN 35.146.

sn12.37:2.1.pli: Tatra kho, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako paṭiccasamuppādaññeva sādhukaṃ yoniso manasi karoti:
sn12.37:2.1.eng: A learned noble disciple carefully and rationally applies the mind to dependent origination itself:

sn12.37:2.2.pli: ‘iti imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjati;
sn12.37:2.2.eng: ‘When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises.
sn12.37:2.2.comm: This abstract principle of dependent origination sometimes precedes or stands for the full set of twelve links. It supplies the verbs that are missing from the bare nouns in the standard sequence: hoti (“is” or “comes to be”) and uppajjati (“arises”). The two phrases use complementary ways of specifying a causal relationship: the first employs the locative absolute to emphasize the presence of the antecedent condition; the second the ablative to emphasize the derivation of the subsequent condition. These two linguistic forms are also used for the twelve links themselves: the normal sequence, as here, uses the ablative form; sometimes we find the locative absolute form (eg. SN 12.49); sometimes both (eg. SN 12.4:15.2). | Later, the abstract principle was sometimes referred to as “specific conditionality” in contrast to the twelve links which are “dependent origination”. While this is a handy distinction, it is not found in the Suttas, where the two terms are synonymous.

sn12.37:2.3.pli: imasmiṃ asati idaṃ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhati, yadidaṃ—
sn12.37:2.3.eng: When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases. That is:
sn12.37:2.3.comm: In translation, it is conventional to differentiate the pronouns for comprehensibility. However, while Pali can readily distinguish “this” from “that”, here we have different forms of the same pronoun idaṁ, chosen to indicate something present. In Upaniṣadic language, the use of repeated demonstrative pronouns asserts absolute identity, which the Buddha subverts (see notes at SN 12.17:5.1, MN 22:15.10, MN 38:2.2, DN 6:15.5). “This”, it turns out, is a constant state of coming into being and disappearing, “arising as one thing and ceasing as another” (aññadeva uppajjati aññaṁ nirujjhati, SN 12.61:4.1).

sn12.37:2.4.eng: Ignorance is a requirement for choices.

sn12.37:2.5.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn12.37:2.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.37:2.7.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

sn12.37:2.9.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’”

sn12.38:1.2.pli: “Yañca, bhikkhave, ceteti yañca pakappeti yañca anuseti, ārammaṇametaṃ hoti viññāṇassa ṭhitiyā.
sn12.38:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, what you intend or plan, and what you have underlying tendencies for become a support for the continuation of consciousness.
sn12.38:1.2.comm: “Intend” (ceteti) and “plan” (pakappeti) play the role of “choices” (saṅkhāra), while “underlying tendencies” (anuseti) stand for “ignorance”. | This Sutta illustrates the threefold pattern (tivaṭṭa) into which dependent origination was later analyzed. The twelve factors are grouped under three headings: ignorance, craving, and grasping are “defilements” (kilesavaṭṭa); choices and continued existence are “deeds” (kammavaṭṭa); the remainder are “results” (vipākavaṭṭa). Within these groups we different synonyms or related terms are used in particular contexts (see eg. SN 12.19). The least fitting in this scheme is bhava, which includes all three, but is counted under “deeds” here as it connects grasping with rebirth.

sn12.38:1.3.eng: When this support exists, consciousness becomes established.
sn12.38:1.3.comm: That is, it takes rebirth in a new life.

sn12.38:1.4.pli: Tasmiṃ patiṭṭhite viññāṇe virūḷhe āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti hoti.
sn12.38:1.4.eng: When consciousness is established and grows, there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.
sn12.38:1.4.comm: It “grows” as the individual grows up and matures, leading to renewal of the cycle (see SN 12.64, SN 22.53, MN 38:28.1).

sn12.38:1.5.pli: Āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbattiyā sati āyatiṃ jāti jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
sn12.38:1.5.eng: When there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future, future rebirth, old age, and death come to be, as do sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn12.38:1.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.38:2.1.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, ceteti no ce pakappeti, atha ce anuseti, ārammaṇametaṃ hoti viññāṇassa ṭhitiyā.
sn12.38:2.1.eng: If you don’t intend or plan, but still have underlying tendencies, this becomes a support for the continuation of consciousness.
sn12.38:2.1.comm: Underlying tendencies manifest as morally potent choices. But we usually don’t make such choices continually; they only occur from time to time. Much of the time there is no active volition, for example, when we are asleep. But so long as the tendencies are still there, one is not freed.

sn12.38:2.2.eng: When this support exists, consciousness becomes established.

sn12.38:2.3.pli: Tasmiṃ patiṭṭhite viññāṇe virūḷhe āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti hoti.
sn12.38:2.3.eng: When consciousness is established and grows, there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.

sn12.38:2.4.pli: Āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbattiyā sati āyatiṃ jāti jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
sn12.38:2.4.eng: When there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future, future rebirth, old age, and death come to be, as do sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn12.38:2.5.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.38:3.1.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, no ceva ceteti no ca pakappeti no ca anuseti, ārammaṇametaṃ na hoti viññāṇassa ṭhitiyā.
sn12.38:3.1.eng: If you don’t intend or plan or have underlying tendencies, this doesn’t become a support for the continuation of consciousness.

sn12.38:3.2.pli: Ārammaṇe asati patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa na hoti.
sn12.38:3.2.eng: With no support, consciousness is not established.

sn12.38:3.3.pli: Tadappatiṭṭhite viññāṇe avirūḷhe āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti na hoti.
sn12.38:3.3.eng: When consciousness is not established and doesn’t grow, there’s no regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.

sn12.38:3.4.pli: Āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbattiyā asati āyatiṃ jāti jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti.
sn12.38:3.4.eng: When there is no regeneration into a new state of existence in the future, future rebirth, old age, and death cease, as do sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn12.38:3.5.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

sn12.39:1.2.pli: “Yañca, bhikkhave, ceteti yañca pakappeti yañca anuseti, ārammaṇametaṃ hoti viññāṇassa ṭhitiyā.
sn12.39:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, what you intend or plan, and what you have underlying tendencies for become a support for the continuation of consciousness.

sn12.39:1.3.eng: When this support exists, consciousness becomes established.

sn12.39:1.4.pli: Tasmiṃ patiṭṭhite viññāṇe virūḷhe nāmarūpassa avakkanti hoti.
sn12.39:1.4.eng: When consciousness is established, name and form are conceived.
sn12.39:1.4.comm: “Conceived” (avakkanti) is one of the synonyms of “rebirth” (SN 12.2:4.2). Without conception, name and form would not take shape (literally “coagulate”) in the womb (DN 15:21.2).

sn12.39:1.5.eng: Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields.

sn12.39:1.6.eng: The six sense fields are requirements for contact.

sn12.39:1.7.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling. …

sn12.39:1.13.eng: sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress come to be.

sn12.39:1.14.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.39:2.1.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, ceteti no ce pakappeti, atha ce anuseti, ārammaṇametaṃ hoti viññāṇassa ṭhitiyā.
sn12.39:2.1.eng: If you don’t intend or plan, but still have underlying tendencies, this becomes a support for the continuation of consciousness.

sn12.39:2.2.eng: When this support exists, consciousness becomes established.

sn12.39:2.3.pli: Tasmiṃ patiṭṭhite viññāṇe virūḷhe nāmarūpassa avakkanti hoti.
sn12.39:2.3.eng: When consciousness is established, name and form are conceived.

sn12.39:2.4.eng: Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields. …

sn12.39:2.5.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.39:3.1.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, no ceva ceteti no ca pakappeti no ca anuseti, ārammaṇametaṃ na hoti viññāṇassa ṭhitiyā.
sn12.39:3.1.eng: If you don’t intend or plan or have underlying tendencies, this doesn’t become a support for the continuation of consciousness.

sn12.39:3.2.pli: Ārammaṇe asati patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa na hoti.
sn12.39:3.2.eng: With no support, consciousness is not established.

sn12.39:3.3.pli: Tadappatiṭṭhite viññāṇe avirūḷhe nāmarūpassa avakkanti na hoti.
sn12.39:3.3.eng: When consciousness is not established and doesn’t grow, name and form are not conceived.

sn12.39:3.4.eng: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease. …

sn12.39:3.5.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
